hints.content: Start by understanding the structure of the binary tree. Each node contains a digit (0-9) and can have up to two children. Focus on how to traverse the tree from the root to each leaf node.

Consider how you would represent the number formed by a root-to-leaf path. As you traverse down the tree, you can build the number by multiplying the current number by 10 and adding the current node's value.
Think about how you can identify leaf nodes. A leaf node is defined as a node that has no left or right children. You will need to check for this condition during your traversal.
You may want to use a depth-first search (DFS) approach to explore each path from the root to the leaves. This can be implemented using recursion or an explicit stack.
As you traverse the tree, keep a running total of the sum of all numbers formed by the paths. You can pass the current number as a parameter to your recursive function.
Remember to handle the case where the tree has only one node. In this case, the sum should simply be the value of that node.
Consider edge cases such as when the tree has multiple leaves at different depths. Ensure that your solution correctly sums all the numbers formed by each unique root-to-leaf path.
When implementing the recursive function, make sure to return the sum of the numbers from both left and right subtrees when you reach a leaf node.
You can visualize the process by thinking of the tree as a series of paths. Each time you reach a leaf, you should add the complete number formed by that path to your total sum.
Your final implementation should return the total sum after traversing all paths. Ensure that you account for all paths and that your recursion handles backtracking correctly.

questionNotes: The binary tree contains digits from 0 to 9 only.
A leaf node is defined as a node with no children.
The number of nodes in the tree is in the range [1, 1000].
The depth of the tree will not exceed 10.
The answer will fit in a 32-bit integer.
